video.title: PHP Programming Language Tutorial - Full Course
video.description:
Learn the PHP programming language in this full course / tutorial. The course is designed for new programmers, and will introduce common programming topics using the PHP language.

⭐️Course Contents ⭐️

⌨️ 1. (0:00) Introduction
⌨️ 2. (1:56) Windows Installation
⌨️ 3. (7:32) Choosing a Text Editor
⌨️ 4. (11:06) Hello World & Setup
⌨️ 5. (20:29) Writing HTML
⌨️ 6. (27:30) Variables
⌨️ 7. (38:09) Data Types
⌨️ 8. (44:27) Working With Strings
⌨️ 9. (54:50) Working With Numbers
⌨️ 10. (1:05:14) Getting User Input
⌨️ 11. (1:15:37) Building a Basic Calculator
⌨️ 12. (1:22:13) Building a Mad Libs Game
⌨️ 13. (1:28:59) URL Parameters
⌨️ 14. (1:35:52) POST vs GET
⌨️ 15. (1:41:44) Arrays
⌨️ 16. (1:50:26) Using Checkboxes
⌨️ 17. (1:57:22) Associative Arrays
⌨️ 18. (2:04:55) Functions
⌨️ 19. (2:12:10) Return Statements
⌨️ 20. (2:19:10) If Statements
⌨️ 21. (2:37:16) If Statements (con't)
⌨️ 22. (2:47:13) Building a Better Calculator
⌨️ 23. (2:56:53) Switch Statements
⌨️ 24. (3:05:09) While Loops
⌨️ 25. (3:15:18) For Loops
⌨️ 26. (3:26:24) Comments
⌨️ 27. (3:31:08) Including HTML
⌨️ 28. (3:36:51) Include: PHP
⌨️ 29. (3:45:57) Classes & Objects
⌨️ 30. (3:56:23) Constructors
⌨️ 31. (4:06:18) Object Functions - PHP - Tutorial 31
⌨️ 32. (4:13:52) Getters & Setters
⌨️ 33. (4:29:17) Inheritance

Course developed by Mike Dane. Check out his YouTube channel for more great programming courses: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCvmINlrza7JHB1zkIOuXEbw

🐦Follow Mike on Twitter: https://twitter.com/GiraffeAcademy

🔗The Giraffe Academy website: http://www.giraffeacademy.com/

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: Patrick Mayer
topLevelComment.text:
Just a tip for people who were getting errors for the $_GET["name"] thing at 1:12:21

PHP, according to stack overflow (which obviously means it's true), didn't used to have an error when you tried to do that before hitting submit, while the newer versions of PHP do. Even though PHP will display an error on your webpage, you can still type in a name and hit submit, which will make the error go away. Hope this saves someone some time.

					#This->Rating = $Ranting;
					$This->SetRanting($Ranting) = $Ranting;
				}Function GetRanting() {
					Return $This->Ranting;
				}Function SetRanting($Ranting) {

					If($Ranting == "G" || $Ranting == "PG" || $Ranting == "PG-13" || $Ranting "R" ||$Ranting "NR") {

topLevelComment.author: Noppa
topLevelComment.text:
Tip for others learning, if you're new to coding in general and don't know this: you can comment what the code is meant to do with //. Just write your comment after the //, and it won't affect the code itself. Works on all(?) languages, and can also be used to temporarily remove a line of code to see if something/anything changes.
This'll help you remember when you look back (and while learning!), and helps others reading the code understand what the line/block should do.

Ex.:  $name[0] = "G"; //replace set character with another; here, first letter becomes G.
or
//echo strtolower(""); //this line isn't active and doesn't affect the code whatsoever. Remove the // in front of "echo" to include again.
or
If you feel like it, I suppose you could also after a long battle with the code comment, //I don't know why this part works now, but it does.

topLevelComment.author: Alexander Hewett
topLevelComment.text:
Problem at approx 1:43:00


Context: I have been creating the entire php.site file including every information from this video. I have not been erasing content within <?php (CONTENT) ?>

Problem: When using $_POST the password is showing in the URL

Solution: a password using the $_POST method must be stored in a separate .php file than 
other code using $_GET or the password will still show in the URL. You cannot combine them in the same file.

Posting for anyone else who needs.

topLevelComment.author: Alexander Hewett
topLevelComment.text:
Problem at 1:08 ..... 

<form action="site.php" method="get">

Context: I have been creating the entire php.site file including every information from this video. I have not been erasing content within <?php (CONTENT) ?>

Error: " Parse error: syntax error, unexpected '<' "

Solution: <form></> cannot be placed WITHIN <?php ?>.....close it out 

I assume "form" is an HTML function....not PHP?

My own Error. Posting for anyone else who messed up.

topLevelComment.author: Alexander Hewett
topLevelComment.text:
syntax issue video tag @ 1 hour:
 $num = num + 25; #adds 25 to original number in the "num" Variable.
should be:
 $num = $num + 25; #adds 25 to original number in the "num" Variable.
MUST ADD "$" before num. The video author messed up here. Posting for anyone who messed up.

topLevelComment.text: Quick question:  I checked the documentation as well as stack overflow for any similar questions, but when I type out exactly what you have and how you have it I am receiving a 'Warning: Undefined array key "name" in (where I stored the file) on line 16'.  Any suggestions? it is now on PHP 8.1  edit: the 1:12:32 mark

replies.author: aantonov1
replies.text: His errors are disabled inside the php.ini file. You receive those errors because before executing your code some or all of your variables do not have a value to them which means they are undefined. After submitting data your error will disappear. If you want to disable errors from showing inside your browser and instead show them in your console you should edit your $errors variable inside the php.ini file.

topLevelComment.author: Eduard Stefan
topLevelComment.text:
For every beginner out there I just want to say something about this. 

First of all great course, Mike, I liked you from the MySQL tutorial as well and I always love seeing you when I watch tutorials. 

Second of all, now this is for beginners. If you're wondering what language is the best for you as the first language. Well, it really doesn't matter. Look I started with Java but I watched this tutorial in 1 hour instead of 5 just because I knew the basics of programming like variables loop, basic OOP and so on. Literally every language uses that. When you're a beginner your focus should not be to learn all the quirks of that language but rather to learn the basics,  the stuff that you meet in every language. After that, you can easily transfer to any language you want. Once you decide which one you want to stick with then it is time to learn the advanced stuff. Good luck to you all and thank you Mike and FreeCodeCamp for these amazing lessons you're the best!

it happened with me also. in CMD change the root , so if it looks like this c:users>marks and you installed PHP  in E: then type while its on C:users>Marks CD .. {CD stands for change disk and the .. is to go back one folder press enter that will move you one folder back so it will be C:Users and then again CD .. then you should have C: then change to the root folder 

type CD E and once you have the cursor saying the main root E: , i guess in your case . then type the php -S localhost:4000 then it should say its active . go to your browser and tybe localhost:4000/your site root/site.php 

then it should work. hope that helps

i just want to say this just in case anyone has any trouble with the document root at 13:36 
the way to change the root is to input this instead for example


php -S localhost:4000 -t C:\(wherever you want)


this will host the server and change the root to the place you want
i had some trouble with this and i wanted to post this just in case anyone had the same trouble

replies.author: Dwayne Hinterlang
replies.text:
Check your path variable contains PHP installation directory.
You can try to use a new terminal window which will use updated environment variables.
If you're using powershell, you can use "refreshenv" command without using a new terminal.
You can check your environment variables loaded by the terminal by typing "set" (Check that path has your php install location)

replies.text:
Oh nevermind what I stated above... I just read in the php docs that "It is recommended that you avoid 'stacking' ternary expressions. Because PHP's behaviour when using more than one ternary operator within a single statement is non-obvious"

So apparently javascript could be more predictable how it handles ternary where php is recommended that you avoid stacking. So in php ternary is only good for simple if/else statements.

I just ran into issues trying to do more complex ternary.

My biggest piece of advice is to just build stuff! Code more and more. Build a Twitter clone. Learn about different things that pho can do, and just try building something big that touches aspects of things you don't know yet or want to learn.

topLevelComment.author: Некто Лохматый
topLevelComment.text: Thank you for this course, Mike. It's good for beginners: everything is explained well and showed by understandable examples. However, the problem about your course (in my opinion) is that it is full of unrequired words. I mean, you would often repeat what you'd said in previous tutorials, read some output (which is not code even, but just English). Especially, the mad&libs game tutorial was unrequired at all, since it didn't bring anything new - it was just another example of what you'd been talking about for the last 3 - 4 tutorials. (Actually, there could be something new if you showed how to hide the output unless the user enters the words; you promised to show this "later in the course", but you didn't). So, ideally you would cut out extra stuff; I guess, there would remain about 1.5 hours of the course, and these 1.5 hours would be very valuable content.

topLevelComment.text: I categorize certain programming language from non-sensitive to sensitive program languages, non-sensitive program languages are languages that is quite hard to get errors too...such as html is a 100% non-sensitive programming language. It all counts for end marks, case-sensitive, how long keys are, and how often it is to get errors that makes up which is non-sensitive and sensitive program languages...and actually, html is 99% non-sensitive because from that form option that shows errors under certain circumstance. java as I found out is actually a really sensitive programming language because of keys and stuffs and complexity.

topLevelComment.author: Noel Gomile
Mattias Aabmets
topLevelComment.text: Your explanation is misleading @  1:21:00 . It would be more accurate to say that when the user presses the submit button, the browser takes the values the user entered into the input boxes and converts them into a URL encoded dictionary and appends it to the base URL and then uses the new updated URL to make a request to the server. You're not seeing the result of the request in the URL, but the request itself before it was made. If you edit the URL manually, then you're editing the request which the browser will make to the server once you press enter. This makes more sense if thought about in this order.

topLevelComment.author: Ryan Nordquist
topLevelComment.text: 4:04:55 Nope, it's not just the two lines you show on your screen that are creating the Book objects with the parameters you have specified; it is the three lines in your constructor PLUS the two lines shown on your screen that are working to create the Book objects with the specified parameters/arguments. Without those three lines in your constructor, the program would not function as intended because without those three lines in your constructor, the program would not understand what the stuff passed as arguments to the constructor mean. So really, this way we're taking eight lines of code down to five.
